title: [K-12] Flipped Learning and Collaborative Problem-Based Bridge Computer-Aided Design Education

context.prior_knowledge: Basic engineering mathematics and CAD software experience
context.additional_context: Curriculum integrating flipped learning with collaborative problem-based learning (CPBL) for bridge design projects in a digital device-enabled environment

learning_goals: Learners can mathematically model fundamental bridge design principles and implement them using CAD tools.

In teams of 4–5, learners will solve two real-world engineering problems (e.g., bridge design, solar power optimization) over three months using CPBL (collaborative problem-based learning). They will document the five-stage design process (problem definition → idea generation → prototyping → testing → improvement) and submit a final presentation meeting four or more out of five evaluation criteria.

In a flipped learning environment, learners will demonstrate self-directed learning competencies by: 1) completing 80% or more of weekly learning videos, 2) scoring 70 or higher on online quizzes, and 3) fulfilling at least three items on a monthly self-assessment checklist. At course completion, they will submit a learning portfolio (error log, concept summaries) and achieve a rating of "average" or higher in three out of four teacher evaluation areas.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
